threads.com:
Welcome to /diy/, a place to:

Post and discuss /diy/ projects, ask questions regarding /diy/ topics and exchange ideas and techniques.

Please keep in mind:
- This is a SFW board. No fleshlights or other sex toys.
- No weapons. That goes to /k/ - Weapons. The workmanship and techniques involved in creating objects which could be used as weapons or the portion of a weapons project that involves them (e.g., forging steel for a blade, machining for gunsmithing, what epoxy can I use to fix my bow) may be discussed in /diy/, but discussing weapon-specific techniques/designs or the actual use of weapons is disallowed. Things such as fixed blade knives or axes are considered tools, things such as swords, guns or explosives are considered weapons.
- No drugs or drug paraphernalia (See Global Rule 1). If you want to discuss something that could involve such things (e.g., carving a tobacco pipe from wood) that's fine, but make sure it's /diy/ related and doesn't involve drugs or it will result in deletion/ban.

Helpful links:
https://sites.google.com/site/diyelmo/
http://www.engineeringtoolbox.com/

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Some friendly suggestions for posting:
- First ask Google, then ask /diy/. Your question will probably be better received if you do so.
- List available resources (tools, materials, budget, time, etc.)
- Try to use pictures and explain the goal, if possible
- Be patient, this is a slow board; your thread will be around for days.
- Share your results! /diy/ loves to see problems solved and projects completed!

All the info you need about 3D-printing: https://pastebin.com/AKqpcyN5
>Your print failed? Go to:
https://www.simplify3d.com/support/print-quality-troubleshooting/

If that doesn't help you solve your print problems, please post:
>A picture of the failed part
>Printer make & model
>Filament type/brand
>Slicer & slicer settings

>What printer should I buy? [Last updated 2022-11-19]
Under 250 USD: kingroon KP3L, Sovol sv01, Creality Ender 3 (v2), Anycubic Mega S
Under 500 USD: Qidi X-One2, Creality CR-10, Anycubic Vyper, Prusa Mini
Under 1000 USD: Prusa i3, Bambu Labs X1
Over 1000 USD: e3d toolchanger, Ultimaker, Qidi X-CF Pro, Build your own Voron, Rat Rig, Prusa XL (lol enjoy the wait)
SLA: Anycubic Photon, Elegoo Mars, Prusa SL1, Formlabs Form 3, Creality HALOT-ONE
Instead of buying a new printer, you could consider building your own: https://reprap.org/wiki/

>Where can I get free things to print?
https://www.thingiverse.com/
https://thangs.com/
https://grabcad.com/
https://google.com/
https://printables.com/
https://www.yeggi.com/

>What CAD software should I use?
Variants of professional parametric CAD programs such as Solidworks (lol paying for software), Fusion360, Inventor, Onshape, TinkerCAD, and AutoCAD may be free depending on your profession, level of piracy and definition of ''free''.
Most anons use Fusion360, but some /g/oobers prefer OpenSCAD or FreeCAD. If you want to do mesh free-forming and modeling, Blender is alright. Also while not necessarily a design program, Meshmixer (free) can be extremely useful for tweaking models to print.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2510048
They are carbide (at least there is no particular reason to believe otherwise) but they aren't going to be suited for cutting plastics. A lot of the cheap imported inserts are actually pretty good when it comes to steel.
They may work alright for printed parts, but my thinking is that a strong blunt edge (typical on general purpose inserts) will be bulldozing the material more than cutting it and compromise the integrity of the bonds between layers. A sharp edge will cut the soft material with less violence.
It's also a good idea to start out grinding your own tools to get a better understanding of the machining process.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2509645
That sounds like your alignment is good, what direction do you have the outer insert pointing towards?

>now it's a little less than a thou over 6 inches from the pocket face
This probably goes without saying, but you are checking this with a known straight tool shank or test bar and as short of an indicator setup as you can get right? The body of the drill isn't supposed to be centered in the hole, if you find center using an indicator from the outer insert to the opposite side of the body it will drill small and you'll have chip issues, there's supposed to be 0.010-0.020" of clearance on the non cutting side.


>C12L14 cold roll, ~1krpm and .003
Without a size I can only really guess, that would be about right for a 2-2.5" drill, do you have any idea what insert grade(s) you're using? With the Sandvik tools and I'm used to and a good general purpose insert, I'd aim for 600-700SFM at a 0.0015-0.002" IPR feed as a starting point, once you get one hole done you can evaluate changes based on the insert condition, feed would be the first thing I'd try to increase. Most of my experience is with specialty HSLA steels and high performance nickel alloys, having some 12L14 for a day would be a pleasant dream, but I don't have any direct experience.

The thing I like to keep in mind is that they're not "drills" in the common sense, it's more like a boring bar that can take a massive cut since the loads are not symmetrically balanced, you've got to throw out a lot of the conventional logic. When they're running correctly they should sound about like this https://youtu.be/0N9ktwuNH9k?t=31 but almost ear piercingly loud, you probably want some form of ear pro when you're using one.

>>2509730

Energy efficiency is paramount if you wanna go cheap.
I would pick DIY home or shed kit, tryng to insulate everithing the best way possibile (it shouldn't be that expensive if the building is small).
Extreme care should be taken against humidity, condensation, and mold formation. Screwing up here can result in a really expensive failure! Animals must be taken into account too.

A simple wood structure, with insulation in between the frames, a protective layer outside, then an air gap and sheet metal as an outermost layer. With the same tecnique and materials you should be able to do both walls and roofs. Some modification whould be needed to flooring, but only for the outermost layer.

You should probably place a vapor barrier somewhere and take into account different details, but this should be the most cost cost efficient, long tesm, high comfort solution.

>>2502717
Really mate?
It's just basic electrical math. All you need to understand is your amps, voltages, and wire losses.
Solar panels are rated at max watts and really 50% their rating average across the day. Keep that in mind for your calculations
Length and gauge of wire to the panels doesn't matter because good charge controllers run at hundreds of volts so you put your panels into series.
Keep your DC charging and battery side short and huge.

I've had my little off grid setup for about 3 years. Recently ran 1500w on the a/c side and it shows the importance of a big ass DC side that I don't have. Still cooked food for 15 minutes straight in my oven thing.

Also, see the capacitor bank on the inverter? That is a very important component for 12v systems and even 24v. It makes the inverter absolutely fuck

last_replies.com: What's the /diy/ method of leveling a bunch of uneven floors in 1880s brick house? Dirt floor basement so thinking of concreting that first and then jacking a bunch of shit up

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2510002
you need a solid/stable foundation so whatever supports the floors you intend to level does not sink or rise and cause unevenness all over again
ive seen situations where they had to come in and drive piles into the earth beneath the basement until they hit some kind of hard pan. then through a an array on driven piles and connecting horizontal beams, they were able to support the floor and get shit back to level

might not be your case, but something to think about. maybe your house settled over time and at some point stopped settling. so if you were to re-level it, it would stay that way for awhile.
on the other hand, if its not done settling, then your level job could end up being a temporary fix

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2510002
>then jacking a bunch of shit up
You must never do this. It'll destroy the house. You can stabilize it and rebuild level floors throughout, but jacking up a house to "re-level" will absolutely fucking destroy it.
If there are things sinking rapidly, stabilize the structure first.
After that, move room to room, pull up the floors and subfloors and add joists that are level, then add subfloors and new flooring.
The pressures you'd put on a house by jacking it up unevenly would literally rip it apart.

Are you not doing this? Holy fuck.

What you're doing is essentially what my father did growing up. All forms of throwing your compostable stuff to the ground and letting it rot and dissolve into the earth is ok, but if you want to have a super-rich soil load every year, composting it in place is best. Turning it over is necessary and if you want to avoid concentrations of certain bacteria, you want to avoid tossing in fats and citrus and a few other things.

THAT said, I used an anaerobic compost barrel last year and produced EXCELLENT fertilizer by tossing all yard waste into a barrel of water and stirring once a week. Smells like an unwashed asshole, but when I applied it, I got the explosive growth I was promised. Additionally, I use an aerobic compost tumbler for my kitchen waste.

My garden kicks ass every year.

Sometimes doing the bare minimum is effective, but not the most beneficial.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2509868
>Is Black+Decker a good brand for wireless drills?
No. They're a low-end line for very basic performance. They're not uselessly bad, but their performance and build quality are only suited to light and occasional use. Things like hanging pictures and working on furniture kits should go fine, but it may struggle for things like building a wooden work bench. Metalwork is probably right out, practically speaking. But they are cheap, so they may be a good choice if that's all you need. Ryobi makes a much more capable line aimed more at a DIYer who actually does projects. The more expensive brands typically offer increased performance for that cost. Do you need to drill half-inch holes in steel without pilot holes? I do, which is why I went with the DeWalt drill that can do that. The M12 line is excellent, but it's designed more for compactness than economy, and it does sacrifice significant power compared to 18V tools. A mid tier 18V line like Ryobi would probably give you more bang for your buck.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
I have an ancient gas oven that's set up to run on a propane tank out back. The stovetop works but the oven part does not. Everything in it is mechanical except the clock and the spark wires that light the gas, so it's not an electrical problem. The gas flow is good enough to light all four stovetop burners on full blast simultaneously.
Inside, when I turn on the oven, it clicks and lights the pilot. The pilot flame comes on after a concerningly long amount of clicking (which I attribute to mice chewing on the wires to the spark), but the rest of the pipe never lights. It is equipped with a mercury capillary-driven safety valve with a bulb over the pilot light, so if the pilot goes out the gas will stop. I have confirmed the safety valve works by removing it, holding a lighter to the bulb, and blowing through where the propane goes. After about 10 seconds of heat on the bulb I can feel it suddenly open up and air comes out where it's meant to. The main pipe the oven flames are supposed to come from is not clogged, it's not even dirty.
It does have a regulator on the back, which I have never touched. I've read online that in many cases the regulator is just for the oven part and if it fails the stovetop will still work. How can I test if the regulator is bad without buying a new one, since it's practically antique? I am soliciting any other ideas for what could be wrong with this thing.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2507869
Do you need to reconfigure it for propane? They don't share the same properties with natural gas. It's not far off, but typically, it needs to be converted for a different flow rate, not just add a different valve to connect to a propane tank. I can't claim to have ever done it, but my friend has an old farm house on hunting land in Wisconsin, and we always have to play with propane shit. Everything there was converted to propane. I've done a lot of shit with it. I just wasn't instrumental in the conversions.

>remember it needs to be able to tilt
Yes, that's why I mentioned hinges.

Am I missing something?
What's the difference, in a single day, between having an fixed panel (tilted to optimal angle) vs having an active tracking setup?
Not talking about a panel, parked in the same place, over a period of months or years. The image you posted doesn't show a day/night cycle, but a winter/summer cycle. That's a completely different scenario (unless you intend this bike trailer to be parked in the same spot for months at a time).

A solar panel attached to a bike trailer is always going to be at human height, easily accessible--no climbing on the roof, etc.
So why automate it at all? Why pay for the electronics & linear actuator? Why haul them around?

Find (or write) a calculator, check it for the optimal angle. Then adjust the thing by hand (wing nut, threaded knob, etc). A little digital angle gauge would give more accuracy than required to check your adjustment.
Do that once a week? Once a day? Whatever makes sense.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2509928
>What's the difference, in a single day, between having an fixed panel (tilted to optimal angle) vs having an active tracking setup?
Well, even on a fixed setup at home it has its benefits, you're going to have a better power output in the end. Check "solar tracking system" on Youtube. But these giant things are probably pretty pricey so yeah, manually tilting the solar panels at the ideal angle for your location and time of the year is the common practice that is good enough and cheap.

The thing is that this is going to be a trailer hauled by an eBike travelling around Europe, and what might be the optimal angle on the first mile/km of your day can at any turn become the opposite: a completely shitty angle, all depending on the varying directions you're going in throughout the day.
"So just have the solar panel flat all the time so that it's good enough in all directions" : sure, that's what most people do on moving vehicles / solar bikes.
But if you have the time and money to make a small system that can have the best angle at all time and all directions, why not go for that? In the end that's extra mileage, it's totally worth it imo. + it's going to be a fun project messing around with the Arduino modules and stuff, I'll learn a lot and in the end and when everything will work it will look good.

Look at what this guy did and you'll see what I'm talking about. This is basically a way more complicated and expensive system than what I'm going to do, but it does look good
https://www.youtube.com/@solarEbike

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:

>>2509944

So basically have the panels flat when you're riding and once you stop at camp or for a break, manually tilt the solar panel at the ideal angle.
But then I thought why not automate it all so that you have the perfect angle even while you're riding? Once again I have the time, the will, the money (it's not even that much extra money, you just need an Arduino with some modules and a linear actuator) and I'm going to learn a ton of stuff during the process. And you end up with better power output, so it's all benefits to me. I'm eager to get started honestly.

last_replies.com:
>>2509379
Most the Miller Falls #1 will be the most useful spoke shave for your needs by a long shot, they are obtainable but you have to be patient. They are not exactly rare but nor are they common, but they are niche enough to keep prices from getting ridiculous or making you have to wait excessively long periods to get one. Generally they run from $60-$100 depending on condition, fair chance you would have to find one in the US to buy, but that has the positive side effect that it is probably worth twice the price in Europe and you will be able to sell it at a profit without much effort if it turns out to not be something you like to use. They take a bit to learn to sharpen well and use but once you get the hang of it there are few tools (if any) as good at dealing with tight inside radii, once you get the hang of it it will leave a finish ready surface and can deal with the complex curves which are a headache with most tools. And they make nice and easy to clean up shavings instead of dust which gets everywhere.

The No. 80 is a scraper plane, not at all a spoke shave and not very useful for your needs.

The card/cabinet scraper will be useful for most finishing needs, they can work most curves with a bit of practice and easily work flat surfaces, they will cut more aggressively than sandpaper and still leave a glass smooth surface in the vast majority of hardwoods. And like the spoke shave, makes shavings instead of dust.

Another thing which might be of use are gun stock scrapers, these are like the #80 but much smaller. They are simple to make and can be made with convex, concave or flat soles and you can often find them on the used market for not terribly much. About halfway between the card scraper and a spoke shave, useful little tools. These have many names, scraper shave is fairly common as is chair devil but chair devils tend to be more designed for rounding/finishing dowels used in chair construction.

>They're not supposed to run anything like an AC, heat pump, fridges, pumps, anything with induction motors.
I've seen a lot of youtubers doing just that. As long as the wattage is enough, all is good.
Are you talking about the power factor?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2508841
I'm talking about startup current. It's not like it never works, but you're exceeding the ratings the device was designed for. A 5000W induction motor would extremely likely blow these 5000W inverters immediately, because a 5000W induction motor can temporarily draw 20-25kW on startup. Ideally you should be using a low frequency inverter. A small split AC can work on the 5000W Bluetti because they have 10kW surge, so in that regard you're just overpaying compared to the $600 solar inverter that can do the same. As a rule of thumb for induction devices, you need to oversize the HF inverter's peak load by a factor of 7.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2509016

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2509130
why not just use a pipe wrench though?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2509016
Lookup "portable valve actuator" and really think about what you're trying to do and what effects it could have if it goes wrong. Opening/closing valves too fast, not knowing valve gate position, or not being able to close a valve once opened, have contributed to killing hundreds of thousands of people globally in industrial accidents since the industrial revolution. If your valves are old and rusty I'm thinking your work site doesn't have adequate facility maintenance and therefore safe practices might be lacking or absent.

I am a system safety engineer, trust me when I say you wouldn't believe the seemingly benign shit people do that ends up being the first domino that triggers catastrophe. Good luck and be safe.

threads.com: I always assumed that a tiny voltage would have trouble moving through a huge wire. That's why we use small wires for low voltage, right? Yet science tells me that in fact smaller wires have higher resistance so the voltage would actually travel though bigger wire better. Is this true? Would 1v travel better though a huge thick mains voltage cable than a small speaker wire??

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2508479
>Too hard to manufacture for the price of making a solid wire of similar ampacity

Go look at the price of a 1" copper plumbing pipe. Then go look at the price of a solid 1" bar of copper. The price difference is huge, and plumbing pipe is DOM tube (a notably more expensive process than welded). Additionally, the exact thing being described already exists and is widespread in the form of braided shielding.

The logic of "hurr durr all that matters is outer diameter" is retarded on its face. Otherwise, you could do shit like run 100A through RG6 no problem. Go try it, tell me how well that goes.

>That's called copper clad wire and its use in industry is well established.

Yeah, and it's used mostly because aluminum is cheaper for a given ampacity than copper. The only reason it's coated in copper is because copper/aluminum junctions are a nightmare scenario for promoting galvanic corrosion. Having aluminum in direct contact with copper will quickly destroy the connection, possibly within mere days if it gets wet with something like salt water. It's also seen where large conductor needs to span a significant length and the weight/strength of copper would be a problem, but bare aluminum wire won't do (again, usually for corrosion/weathering reasons).

Go look at literally any of the NEC charts dictating the maximum amp rating for copper wire and CCA wire of the same gauge. They're not even close. You know why? Because the whole wire is conducting, not just the outer surface.

>XT90S connector

The only issue is that they use solder cups. Soldered connections effectively solidify a wire at the joint and negate the benefits of high-strand wires. You can mostly counteract the issue by securing the wires/connector as solidly as possible near the joint. It doesn't really matter if the connections are more brittle if they're prevented from moving in the first place.

What do you guys like for modern production environment design?

I found this firm in my country that uses stainless tubes to configure all sorts of tables, carts etc. Also there's MayTec and Bosch/Rexroth that use mostly extruded aluminium profiles, these two also have their own CAD software to allow quick configuration of all sorts of setups, which is nice.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
I work at a Toyota subsidiary, and we use Toyota Production System (many influences on modern lean ideas). I'm in the US.
We use a huge amount of the pipe & joint stuff. The same kind of thing you reference as "stainless tubes". Vendor lock-in is the unfortunate reality. For the first few years we sourced stuff from Creform, then switched to PAC. That second compnay does not show up readily in search results unless you search the full name 'Production Automation Corporation'. Same size parts are generally interchangeable, but the fit is off--like putting together LEGO and MegaBloks.

One advantage for this kind of system is that reworking a station, cart, bench, etc takes one day, or an off-shift. It's easy and fast enough that you can iterate on designs. Just keep a cabinet with the most common parts, some extra tubes, etc. A big benefit for me is that the workers/users can do simple repairs/mods. If something is loose, or misaligned, or needs moved 1" to the left, they can do it with a set of hex keys. If you know someone isn't a retard, you can also give them a tubing cutter & deburr tool--lete them do the work vs trying to explain it.

Last, I'll mention that we did some test setups with 80 20 aluminum extrusion. One guy had a hardon for it. I'm pretty sure it's on the "We tried it, and it doesn't hold up the like steel tubes do" list forever.

total energy=mgh ; if we assume height to be 1m

What i've discovered after having some heavy rain on a recently erected prefab:
>tannalised / pressure treated wood is a must
>avoid shitlap and go for tongue and groove
>be generous with weather resistant paint
>fill any huge interior gaps with weather resistant expanding foam and trim as needed
>fill any joints between panels and exterior gaps with weather resistant sillicone sealant or similar
>install regular house size guttering
>have good concrete paving foundation raised above ground level by an inch or two
>ensure that any hard ground / exposed foundation around the edges of the shed has either guttering above or somehting to deflect rainwater splashback away from the wood
>allow an inch or so in between the foundations and the floor of the shed for ventilation

https://ww w.finewoodworking. com/2008/03/21/a-benchtop-bench

Synopsis: Woodworking benches are designed to place the workpiece at a height that’s ideal for handplaning. But that height is often too low for routing and handwork. Furniture maker Jeff Miller built a mini-bench that elevates workpieces to a more comfortable height.

Extraction woodworking benches are designed to place a workpiece at a height that’s ideal for handplaning. But the perfect height for planing often is too low for other common bench tasks. For example, when routing, carving, cutting dovetails, or doing layout, I frequently have found myself bent over at an uncomfortable angle so that I could see clearly and work effectively. When performing these tasks, I like to have a workpiece positioned 6 in. to 10 in. above my waist level.

To bring a workpiece to my ideal height range, I made a small workbench that mounts quickly to my regular bench. When extra height is needed, the minibench effectively raises the work-surface to my comfort zone. The bench is easy to move, stores nicely under my bigger bench, and includes a vise that provides plenty of holding force.

We just kept a spray bottle with a stream nozzle next to it, and did the pre-lining with TP to minimize that.

The knife type valve that closes off the holding tank from the bowl needs to be kept free of mineral deposits so the rubber seal doesn't get damaged and leak but even with full time use that just meant using some vinegar or CLR every 6-8 months or so and maybe some gentle scraping with a plastic scraper.
Never had a leak in use or when carrying it upright where that valve is keeping the sewage in, or with the swiveling pour spout and cap.
We definitely babied it for fear of breaking something and having a mess, but it worked great. One thing we did was build a small base to bring it up to a taller height to minimize the inertia of someone sitting on it that might stress it enough to break something.

Basically, since the two faucets are both at the same height in the tower, if they were identical then the back of each faucet would crash in to each other. So one of them has a longer pig tail in the back so that it can go over the back of the first faucet and connect to the second service line.
Again, not the most astounding revelation or anything, but I thought it was of note.

Arduino
>The system should turn on after pressing S1 S2 and S3 sequentially
Use a variable for a flag. Set it to 0

Then use a loop that runs until the flag=3{
If s1 is pressed, set the flag to 1
If s2 is pressed set the flag to 2 if it's currently 1, otherwise set it back to 0
If s3 is pressed set the flag to 3 if it's currently 2, otherwise set it back to 0
}

>light sequence
Use an infinite loop{
Turn on green light
wait 10 sec
Turn off green and turn on orange
wait 2 sec
... continue for full sequence
}

Look up how to blink an LED with an arduino, then look up how to poll buttons

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: I would put it in a box and pour some sort of liquid rubber around it.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2505931
That and for handling OP could fab a simple cart (because bending over is bad) to hold the mould in a removable tray. If you're going to do something many times it's wise to make it easy.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2505917
What would be best depends on how many you need to make, also you don't show the edge detail on the far side...but assuming it's a typical pool coping tile with a square edge there I would cast a plaster mold oriented like picrel where that RH piece is flat stock (could be wood or metal) that comes off and you tilt the finished casting up and out. You could probably count on shrinkage (and an accurate plug) and liberal mold release to make the sides pop loose and keep it to two parts, or make the sides separate and strap it all together with a ratchet strap before pouring.
Rubber would work too but isn't necessary for that little detail and breaks down faster.
Just wax the hell out of the plaster so its sealed, apply a mold release over that when it's assembled, and you're good to go.
Also fwiw for that kind of part you can also make an extra long mold of that profile and have fitted plugs to dam off the ends at different lengths for longer/shorter/multiple tiles, to make miters, interlocking ends, etc.

threads.com: What's /diy/s opinion of cob? Finding tons of absolutely beautiful builds online and I've always been enamoured with earthships and undergrounds/hobbit holes. Would it be worth it or does the material suck? Even if I just make a studio it doesn't look like it would take much to just add on to it.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2502905
It's incredibly cheap to build and also very DIY friendly.

The biggest problem with it is that it's very time consuming. Each layer has to set and you've got to allow for shrinkage.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2502388
>Would it be worth it or does the material suck?
theres nothing really wrong with it although it has advantages and disadvantages versus other materials for any given application.
IMO the main problem with cob is the immense amount of physical labor to get it done.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2502388
Depends on the climate and environment. If your country or county is rich in cob, it's a cheap material and depending on the way it's built, it can be easier to build alone than laying bricks. The best climate is if you live in a normal or dryer climate.
As methods, you can look up example traditional hungarian cob houses. They used (sometimes not) woven net as basic wall structure, and layer by layer plastered cob on it. They made half meter thickness usually. The positive side to it that summer was always cool inside and the air quality is top notch, never dry, and with the good lime plaster it never gets wet. Bad side is that they had to make huge roof over hanger to avoid wetness from rain. They painted the wall yearly again as protection.
An other, more geometrical method: Look up japanese cob wall installations. They build it wall by wall or panel by panel where they use a wire mesh so it holds the cob and gives more flexibility to the walls, but the weight holding structure is wood there.

Veg tan is the way to go, thickness depends entirely on what you are making. You're not going to make a good wallet out of the thick stuff, and you can't make a good belt out of the thin stuff.
